Award.AwardTitle: TC: Small: Collaborative Research: Protecting Networks from Large-Scale Physical Attacks and Disasters

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Telecommunication networks play a vital role in all sectors of our society and are especially important during a crisis. Since networks rely on physical infrastructure (e.g., fibers and routers), they are vulnerable to natural disasters, such as earthquakes and floods, or physical attacks, such as an Electromagnetic Pulse (EMP) attack. This project studies the impact of a disaster or attack on the telecommunications infrastructure and develops mechanisms to mitigate their effect. The project considers events that cause a large number of failures in a specific geographical region. It uses probabilistic and geometric failure models that take into account the geography of the network and the attack characteristics. Under these models, techniques to identify the most vulnerable parts of the network are developed. Moreover, tools to provide a-priori protection plan are designed. Finally, restoration algorithms that will improve the resilience of the network are developed. The project will provide a fundamental understanding of the vulnerability of networks to disasters or attacks. It will also provide network algorithms to mitigate the impact of, and recover from, such failures. Therefore, it has the potential to significantly enhance the availability and performance of networks in the event of attacks and disasters. This is crucial for disaster recovery, especially in today?s society that is increasingly reliant on the availability of a communications infrastructure. In addition, the broader impacts will include outreach activities to school children, and incorporation of the results into advanced graduate classes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Telecommunication networks and power grids play a vital role in the day-to-day routine of all sectors of our society. However, these networks heavily rely on physical infrastructures, and therefore, are vulnerable to natural disasters, such as earthquakes or floods, as well as to physical attacks, such as an Electromagnetic Pulse (EMP) attack. Physical attacks or disasters affect a specific geographical area and will result in failures of neighboring components.

Therefore, in this project we studied effects of physical failures (e.g., of fibers or power lines) and considered geographically correlated failures (i.e., events that cause a large number of failures in a specific geographical region).

In particular, in the context of communications networks, we focused on deterministic and probabilistic failures, on a single failure event and multiple failure events (including multiple failure events exhibiting probabilistic characteristic), and on planned attacks and randomly located attacks/disasters. The probabilistic failure models are important, since network components in the vicinity of an attack/disaster are more likely to fail than those further away. Moreover, we considered cases in which the network has a protection plan in place. For all these cases, we developed algorithms for network vulnerability analysis. We also considered algorithms for route discovery, which identify routes that exhibit better resilience to geographically correlated attacks, compared to other routing methods.

In the area of power grid resilience, we developed models for cascade propagation prediction and explored control mechanisms that can mitigate the effect of an attack. Through numerical experiments with real grid data, we studied the effects of geographically correlated outages and the resulting cascades and showed that the results significantly differ from those predicted by epidemic/percolation based models. The results provided new insights into the cascade propagation models and can provide insight into the design of smart grid measurement and control algorithms that can mitigate a cascade.

Finally, we considered communication networks that depend on the power grid for their power supply, and developed tools to analyze the interdependencies between the networks.

The broader impact includes the potential to contribute to homeland security and public safety efforts. Moreover, the project provided training to various student populations engaged in STEM research. The educational activities include mentoring graduate and undergraduate students, incorporating some of new theory and algorithms into advanced graduate networking classes, and outreach activities to K-12 students. Students and postdocs that were supported by this project have taken on positions in academia and research labs. High school students that participated in the project joined undergraduate programs in top schools.
